marytts.unitselection.select

Class PrecompiledJoinCostReader

  • java.lang.Object
    • marytts.unitselection.select.PrecompiledJoinCostReader
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    JoinCostFunction

    public class PrecompiledJoinCostReader
extends Object
implements JoinCostFunction
    Loads a precompiled join cost file and provides access to the join cost.

    • Method Detail

      • init

        public void init(String configPrefix)
          throws MaryConfigurationException
        Initialise this join cost function by reading the appropriate settings from the MaryProperties using the given configPrefix.
        Specified by:
        init in interface JoinCostFunction
        Parameters:
        configPrefix - the prefix for the (voice-specific) config entries to use when looking up files to load.
        Throws:
        MaryConfigurationException - if there is a configuration problem

      • load

        public void load(String fileName,
        InputStream dummy,
        String dummy2,
        float dummy3)
          throws IOException,
                 MaryConfigurationException
        Load the given precompiled join cost file
        Specified by:
        load in interface JoinCostFunction
        Parameters:
        fileName - the file to read
        dummy - not used, just used to fulfil the join cost function interface
        dummy2 - not used, just used to fulfil the join cost function interface
        dummy3 - Relative weight of the signal-based join costs relative to the phonetic join costs computed from the target
        Throws:
        IOException - if a problem occurs while reading
        MaryConfigurationException

      • cost

        public double cost(Target t1,
          Unit uleft,
          Target t2,
          Unit uright)
        Return the (precomputed) cost of joining the two given units; if there is no precomputed cost, return Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY.
        Specified by:
        cost in interface JoinCostFunction
        Parameters:
        t1 - the left target
        uleft - the proposed left unit
        t2 - the right target
        Returns:
        a non-negative number; smaller values mean better fit, i.e. smaller cost.
